title: Seaweed boom? - The global market for seaweed could see significant growth; can the U.S. get in on the aquaculture and ecological wave?
author: Mike Sunnucks; APG National Enterprise Editor
content:
Seaweed boom? - The global market for seaweed could see significant growth; can the U.S. get in on the aquaculture and ecological wave?

 September 11, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks; APG National Enterprise Editor | Page: A1 | Section: News 
 
 1208
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Is there a future for seaweed farming in the U.S.?Could seaweed farming see a big global aquaculture boom - along with helping clean up ocean waters challenged by climate change and environmental degradations via natural filtering systems?Rafael Cuevas Uribe and Rick Zechman want to find out - and see potential on both fronts.Zechman is associate dean of marine operations and Cuevas Uribe is a fisheries biology professor at California State Polytechnic University, Humboldt (Cal Poly Humboldt).They are leading a new university effort to farm seaweed (bull kelp) off the far northern coast of California.They want to see if the U.S. can boost its overall production of seaweed - which serves as a natural cleaning filter for bodies of saltwater confronted by climate change and in need of environmental remediation.Right now, the U.S. seaweed farming is concentrated in Maine, Hawaii and Alaska, according to the Cal Poly researchers.U.S. kelp and seaweed production is barely a blip in a marketplace dominated by China, Indonesia and other Asian markets in a sector that is projected to grow to $14.3 billion by 2028, according to research firm IMARC Group.The Cal Poly school created a seaweed farm in 2019 leasing space in Humboldt Bay from the local harbor district. It recently harvested a small crop of kelp from that farm.Cuevas Uribe said the school's operation is for research purposes."Our system is purely experimental. A commercial operation would be much larger," he said.Graduate students help work the farm and with research into its production and viability. Its most recent harvest entailed analyzing kelp planted onto various types of ropes "to test growth rates and viability" with the aim of helping "future aquaculture entrepreneurs," according to the school.· MARKETPLACE AND GROWTH POTENTIALSeaweed (or kelp) can be farmed for food and dietary uses - including sushi nori as well as for uses in soups, salads and snacks. It is an especially popular food in Asia, but could see growth as global diets look for alternatives to traditional proteins and face food insecurity challenges spurred by climate change and geopolitical conflicts.Zechman said certain types of seaweed can be used in biotechnology and pharmaceuticals as part of compounds and ingredients. Seaweed has long had herbal and homeopathic uses.Brooklyn-based business research firm IMARC pegs the worldwide commercial seaweed market at $7.5 billion in 2022, according to a new analysis released late last month. The group sees the industry growing to $14.3 billion by 2028 with an 11.64% annual growth rate between 2023 and 2028."The rising demand for seaweed in dietary supplements, owing to its nutritive content, flavor-enhancing, and weight loss properties, is primarily catalyzing the global seaweed market," IMARC writes in its August analysis.That bullish outlook has plenty of company.An Aug. 30 market analysis by Redding, California-based Meticulous Market Research Pvt. Ltd., sees significant growth potential with seaweed-based fertilizers."Recently, there has been a growing interest in seaweed fertilizers for higher crop production and soil quality improvement. Seaweed nutrients boost plant growth, enhance soil fertility, improve crop yield, and boost plant resistance to diseases and pests. This can reduce the need for inorganic fertilizers and pesticides, leading to safer food production," the group writes in its research report.Fertilizer supply chains have also been recently challenged by U.S. and European sanctions against Russia and Belarus - two of the leading fertilizer producers - over the Ukraine war.Another August report by the World Bank sees substantial growth in the seaweed aquaculture space.The international financial institution sees the potential for a $11.8 billion boom in growth in seaweed farming by 2031 with potential gains in using seaweeds/kelps in pet food, animal feed, nutritional supplements, protein alternatives and methane reducing additives."Seaweed farming demonstrates how development, climate and nature work together to generate value and uplift communities. Seaweed farming will be a source of nutrition security as well as an alternative to synthetic fertilizer," said Martien van Nieuwkoop, World Bank's global director for agriculture and food in a statement last month on the growth potentials.· HELPING THE OCEANS, ECOSYSTEMS AND THE PLANETFor Zechman, it's not just about monetary gains and an industry boom. He sees more seaweed cultivation as a way to help clean up ocean waters.He said seaweed in animal feed could reduce methane emissions from cows.The world's 1 billion cows produce an estimated 40% of global methane emissions through manure and 'burping' - a contributor to climate change, according to the Environmental Defense Fund.Seaweed-based animal feed could help reduce cow burps and flatulence.Zechman said kelp beds off the California coast have been decreasing significantly because of a decline in sea stars. The sea stars feed on sea urchins, which feed on kelp and seaweed. More sea urchins mean less seaweed which helps keep ocean waters clean via their natural filtering."The technology that's involved in starting a farm for seaweed can also be used for conservation," he said.· U.S. growth and market potentialSo, what about the U.S. getting in on a potential seaweed boom?Global seaweed aquaculture production has grown to 35 million tons annually.Data from FAO in 2019 showed North American seaweed production at 23,000 tons.Ninety-eight percent of the seaweed harvested globally over the past two decades has occurred in Asia with China (57%) and Indonesia (29%) leading the marketplace, according to a 2022 study by researchers with China's Fujian Agriculture and Forestry University.Other major seaweed cultivating markets include South Korea, the Philippines and Japan. Isolated and food-challenged North Korea has accounted for 1.68% of the world's seaweed farming, according to Fujian researchers' analysis.Currently, U.S production is barely a blip in the global marketplace.The Western Hemisphere has only accounted for 1.36% of global seaweed/kelp farming the past two decades, according to U.N. Food and Agriculture Organization date cited in the Fujian study.Chile has accounted for 88% of the total.That's where the Cal Poly efforts come in, according to Cuevas Uribe and Zechman.They want to see how their farming efforts work out and whether more cultivation can be brought to California, the Pacific coast and other domestic coastlines.Cuevas Uribe said pollution levels and other external factors such as oil drilling and other commercial marine uses could mean the waters are not clean enough for seaweed farming for food production and other commercial uses.But seaweed aquaculture and its natural filtering could help those same bodies of water - including the dead zones and environmentally challenged areas of the Gulf of Mexico and Chesapeake Bay, according to the U.S.National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.Kelp forests can grow along coastal areas in temperate climates, such as the Puget Sound, helping fish and other marine life, according to NOAA.Seaweed is best grown and cultivated on coastlines with inlets and protected bays."It requires fairly calm inland waters," Cuevas Uribe said, pointing to places such as the Atlantic coastline of Maine. "It's got to be sheltered waters."

title: Partner of oyster company petitions for dissolution - Petition follows history of legal violations by company's other partners
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Partner of oyster company petitions for dissolution - Petition follows history of legal violations by company's other partners

 October 19, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: A3 | Section: News

 STEVENSVILLE-A majority partner at Orchard Point Oyster Company is petitioning to judicially dissolve the company due to the two other partners' previous legal violations.The petition, filed Oct. 2 in Queen Anne's County Circuit Court by Orchard Point partner Hal McBee, asks the court to dissolve the company, appoint a receiver to take charge ofits assets and operations, and later liquidate these assets.The need for the petition, McBee said, stemmed from his ongoing concerns with the actions ofOrchard Point's two other partners, Scott Budden and Brian Connelly, and the duo's alleged mishandling ofthe company's operations.After Orchard Point's formation in 2018, the three men were appointed to different roles: Budden as president, Connelly as treasurer and McBee as secretary.Budden and McBee each have 40% ofstocks in the company and Connelly has 20%.Both Budden and Connelly share the responsibility ofmaintaining Orchard Point's permits and registration cards.Though McBee was only responsible for Orchard Point's nursery, which is located at his personal residence, his name is on the aquaculture lease used by the whole company.As the lease holder, McBee said he was made aware earlier this year that the company was operating without renewed permits for 2023 and attempted to stop the two other partners from continuing their work.But when McBee headed into the office one day, he heard the fridge running and discovered 3,000 freshly harvested oysters obtained without an up-to-date permit-a blatant violation, which prompted him to approach the Maryland Natural Resources Police in March.In an interview, McBee said he felt reporting his partners was the only thing he could do. And if he didn't report it, he would be part of the problem, he said.All three men were charged with numerous Department ofNatural Resources permitting violations in April, including. Charges were later dropped for McBee.Budden and Connelly were both found guilty ofengaging in aquaculture without a permit on July 6. Each received probation before judgment and several hundred dollars in fines.And on July 7, Budden was again charged by DNR with failing to obtain a permit for not having authorization for wet storage and operating wet storage outside the boundaries ofa lease in connection to issues in 2022.The lease in question was under McBee's and Connelly's names.McBee's petition also asserts that Orchard Point is operating under McBee's Tidal Fish Dealer license, a state-issued license that gives the company the ability to process, pack, resell, market or deal fish caught in tidal waters.In the petition, an attorney for McBee said the continued use ofhis license by the company, especially considering past unlawful oyster harvesting, creates a risk to him and administrative action from the DNR.Damages to property McBee contributed to Orchard Point were also raised as points of contention.According to the petition, McBee allowed the company to use two ofhis workboats, a 3,600 square-foot office space converted into an oyster processing plant with offices, two residential properties in Stevensville and various pieces of aquaculture equipment.The workboats were utilized under the assurance from Budden and Connelly that Orchard Point would purchase the two boats for their original cost - $150,000. However, the boats were never purchased and no rent was paid for the use ofthe two boats, according to the petition. Failure to properly maintain the boats also incurred damages in excess of$30,000.The two other partners of Orchard Point vacated the company's Stevensville office space on Sept. 1 and failed to remit additional rent or remove alterations made to the office, resulting in property damage ofover $25,000, the petition stated.McBee's capital contributions and loans since 2018 totaled over $250,000 in financing and tangible property.According to the petition, the relationship between McBee and Orchard Point's other shareholders has "deteriorated to a point where Mr. McBee is no longer consulted regarding Orchard Point's operations or finances."Budden declined to comment on the peti-tion. The Star Democrat was unable to reach Connelly in time for publication ofthis article.No further documents have been filed in the circuit court at this time.

title: Comptroller Lierman visits Eastern Shore
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Comptroller Lierman visits Eastern Shore

 October 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 638
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - On the second of four stops to visit businesses on the Eastern Shore on Thursday, Maryland Comptroller Brooke Lierman met with the Dorchester County Council and Johnny Shockley, owner and founder Blue Oyster, an aquaculture business, at the Packing House."It's a beautiful day and (I'm) just excited to come learn more about what's going on and how we can be helpful," Lierman said.Also on her Eastern Shore tour, Lierman visited the Perdue Henson Junior Achievement Center in Salisbury, Sunburst Pharm in Cambridge and For All Seasons in Easton.At the Packing House, Lierman toured Blue Oyster's processing facility, which is still under construction.Shockley walked Lierman and Dorchester County Council President Lenny Pfeffer through Blue Oyster's space, detailing the company's plans for what the space will look like when it is finished.He explained the process of the oysters being brought into the facility, processed and sent out to market.Shockley also showed Lierman where in the Packing House Blue Oyster plans to put in a raw bar and a patio for patrons to sit outside.Shockley said they wants to bring the oyster industry to a 21st century standard.According to its website, Blue Oyster provides oysters to Chesapeake oyster farmers, purchases those oysters when they are grown and delivers them to global markets."What Johnny Shockley and his team are doing at Blue Oyster is incredibly innovative and important for the health of the Bay, but also in creating a new sector of the economy and supporting the aquaculture industry in our state," Lierman said.After the tour, Lierman, Shockley, Pfeffer and Dorchester County Council Vice President Mike Detmer met privately. Shockley said they would be talking about the future of the oyster industry."With respect to environmental markets, with respect to creating a new, better way forward for the watermen to be able to profit, not only from the products they bring in, but also from the results and the value of those products once they go out in the market," he added.Shockley said it was "fantastic" to give Lierman a tour. He said he wants Lierman to know how beneficial oysters can be in cleaning up the Chesapeake Bay. He called oysters "mother nature's natural filtration system." "We've now got some guidelines on how we can use oysters to do that work, to clean that water, based on an economic incentivized platform," he said. "The watermen community can be a major player in making those things happen." Before the tour began, Pfeffer said he was excited to show Lierman "all of the wonderful things that are going on here." "I hope that we can continue (the) great relationship that Dorchester County has with the comptroller's office," he said.On her final stop in Easton, Lierman learned more about the Eastern Shore's designated regional navigator for trafficking victims, For All Seasons."When I was a state delegate, I set up legislation to create a system of regional navigators for trafficking victims so that they would always have one designated place to go in their area," she said.Lierman said she is learning about the work For All Seasons does in behavioral health and rape crisis treatment.After that final stop, Lierman said she was off to to the Supreme Court of Maryland to commemorate a judge."It's always great to be on the Shore," she said of her visit.Reporter Tom McCall contributed to this article.

title: Crabby Christmas - Watermen Usher In Holidays At Annual Event
author: Laura Tayman; Ltayman@Chespub. Com
content:
Crabby Christmas - Watermen Usher In Holidays At Annual Event

 December 11, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Laura Tayman; Ltayman@Chespub. Com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 521

 Read News Document

 With a countdown from ten to one, a large crowd led Santa and Mrs. Claus to turn on a switch and light the three crab basket trees next to Fishermen's Inn at the recent Queen Anne's County Waterman's Association's Tree lighting and Vendor Fair event."I'm surprised that despite the weather we are seeing a steady crowd," Gigi Windley of the Kent Narrows Development Foundation said.
"This is a great cooperative effort from the sponsors to the basket painters to the watermen themselves." The event began during Covid, when Joey and Karen Sadler of Captain's Pride Charters in the Kentmorr Marina said they wanted to create an outdoor benefit event where the community could gather together safely once again.
With the leadership of the Queen Anne's County Waterman's Association, volunteers put the crab basket tree concept together in record time in 2020.
Christy Wilkins coordinates the basket trees effort, starting in October, where crab baskets are sold to local residents and businesses who would paint them and return for the tree display.
This year, nearly 300 baskets were used.
Wilkins said proceeds from the basket sales and the accompanying vendor fair would go towards the watermen's oyster restoration project, to assist watermen who had fallen on hard times because of illness or boat expenses, and, new this year, for scholarships to local high school students in the county.
Over 20 vendors, many with items of a nautical theme, were there for eager holiday shoppers, including Turtles & Tides, the Knotty Mermaid Crochet and Chesapeake Scene Photography.
The Queenstown Lions Club manned the kids craft table, and the Kent Island Rotary sold their "Tales & Tastes of Kent Island" book with students from Club Interact of Kent Island High School. And Fisherman's Inn donated cocoa and apple cider to benefit the Not My Child Program.
As the skies began darkening, the crowd began gathering at the site of the trees, waiting for a special guest to light up the area. Bob Timms of Kent Island Methodist Church gave a blessing of the fleet and Captain Buck Lynch, of the "Stephanie II" Head Boat and representing the Waterman's group, gave moving welcoming remarks.
"We need you and you need us," he told the crowd.
"By working together we can make things better." Sounds of sirens came moments later with shouts of "Santa" by the youngest attendees. Sure enough, here he and Mrs. Claus came, escorted by members of the Kent Island Volunteer Fire Department.
Commissioner Jack Wilson attended the event, and he estimated that the crowd was three times more than in previous years.
"I love this event," Wilson said. "Here we highlight the important work of the watermen in our own community.
This is what small town America is all about."

title: Appreciating oysters
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Appreciating oysters

 January 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1416
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Having grown up on the Eastern Shore, the oyster has been a much-appreciated seafood in my life.My mother made some of the greatest tasting oyster fritters on the Mason Dixon line. There are no watermen in my family, but we lived close enough to the water to respect the life of the waterman and the delicious delicacies that were a result of their hard work.
In our local area here, the most popular oyster varieties include Malpeques, Well Fleet, Blue Points, Delaware Bay, Chesapeake Bay, Chincoteagues, Apalachicola Bay and Gulf Coast.
East Coast oysters range from slightly salty to sharp salt flavor (Chesapeake, Delaware and Gulf Coast oysters have a light salt taste; all others have a sharper salty taste).
The Chesapeake Bay has been home to oystering since the early 19th century. Chesapeake Bay skipjacks are the last commercial sailing vessels in the United States.
The dredge boats once numbered in the thousands. Today only about a dozen or so remain.
Skip jacks are limited to 150 bushels of oysters daily. The dredging season runs from November through March 1. The recent ice has made it impossible for the boats to get out to perform their work — cutting into the ice and cutting into the pockets of our waterman and their families. Check your local newspapers and the Facebook posts of local fire departments, churches and organizations with upcoming oyster dinners and roast coming up for their fundraising events.
I know that many seafood markets are featuring fresh oysters in the shell or by the pint and quarts or opened for you. I like to open my own — eating them on the half shell or cooking them fresh.
Try going down to the docks and getting them from the waterman themselves. Support a trade that is slowly leaving our Eastern Shore. Thank a waterman who goes out in all kinds of weather laboring in a trade they must love that is full of obstacles. The weather has cleared, and the watermen are returning to the trade they love. I am on the way to the docks for oysters to prepare some of my favorite seafood dishes.
EASTERN SHORE OYSTER FRITTERS
Drain 1 quart of oysters, reserving the juice, and set aside. Beat 2 eggs, add the reserved juice to the egg and add Worcestershire sauce to taste. Add 1 1/2 cups flour with 1 1/2 tsps baking powder and mix well. Add the oysters and lightly mix. Fry in hot oil, browning on both sides. Drain on a paper towel and serve warm. When dropping the fritters in the oil, make sure you have at least 3 oysters to a fritter.
TRADITIONAL MARYLAND OYSTER STEW
In a large saucepan, cook one-pint fresh shucked oysters, with juice, over low heat until edges begin to curl. Add 1 quart of milk, 1/4 cup butter, salt and pepper to taste. You can sprinkle some Old Bay seasoning on top if desired slowly, but do not boil. Serve hot with oyster crackers if desired.
SCALLOPED OYSTERS
In a greased two-quart casserole, place alternate layers of oysters and fresh cracker crumbs, doting each layer with butter. For this process you will need one quart of oysters with liquid, 2 to 3 cups fresh crushed crackers and 1/2 cup butter or 1 stick margarine. You can also sprinkle each layer with salt and pepper to taste. End with a layer of crumbs, and pour one to two cups of milk over the top. Dot the top with remaining butter or margarine and bake at 350 degrees until browned, about 40 to 50 minutes. Makes 6 generous servings.
OYSTER POT PIE
In a large saucepan place 5 or 6 diced potatoes, cleaned and peeled, with 5 or 6 carrots, 2 to 3 cleaned and diced onions, 1/2 pound of chopped ham, and 4 strips of uncooked bacon. Cook until done and add salt and pepper to taste. Sprinkle with 1/2 tsp parsley flakes and 1/2 tsp oregano. Mix 1 pint crushed tomatoes and the liquor of one pint of oysters. Add this to the already cooked ingredients. Bring to a boil; thicken with some cornstarch. When thick, add one pint of oysters. Cook until the oysters have curled edges. Pour into a baking dish lined with your favorite crust and place a crust over the top. Slightly prick the top crust with a fork, bake at 400 degrees until brown. This is so delicious for supper on a wintry day.
BACON OYSTER LETTUCE TOMATO
1 cup all-purpose flour, 1 cup cornmeal, 1 tbsp garlic powder, 1 tbsp onion powder, 1/4 tsp cayenne pepper, Kosher salt, freshly ground pepper, 2 dozen oysters (freshly shucked), 12 slices thick-cut bacon, vegetable oil (for frying; about 5 cups), 8 slices brioche or white sandwich bread toasted, mayonnaise, bibb lettuce, and sliced tomatoes. Whisk flour, cornmeal, garlic powder, onion powder, and cayenne in a medium bowl; season with salt and pepper. Working in batches, toss oysters in flour mixture, transfer to a plate. Working in batches, cook bacon in a large skillet, preferably cast iron, over medium heat until crisp, 10–12 minutes per batch; drain on paper towels. Pour oil into a skillet with bacon fat to a depth of one inch and heat over medium-high heat until oil bubbles immediately when a pinch of cornmeal mixture is added. Working in batches, fry oysters, turning occasionally, until golden brown and crisp, about four minutes. Drain on paper towels, season with salt and pepper. Build sandwiches with mayonnaise, lettuce, tomatoes, bacon and fried oysters and serve.
OYSTER CORNBREAD STUFFING
8 tbsps unsalted butter (divided), 4 stalks celery (finely chopped), 1/2 yellow onion (finely chopped), 1 tsp kosher salt, 1 tsp rubbed sage, 1 tsp dried rosemary, 1 tsp dried thyme, 1/2 tsp coarse ground black pepper, 6 cups cornbread cubes, 18 ounces oysters (chopped, liquor reserved), 2 cups chicken broth, 2 large eggs. Preheat oven to 350 degrees and spray a 9x13 baking dish with vegetable oil spray. Add 4 tbsps unsalted butter to a large skillet on medium heat. Add in the celery and onions, cook for 6-8 minutes until translucent. Add in the salt, sage, rosemary, thyme, and black pepper and stir. To a large bowl add the cornbread cubes, vegetable mixture, and oysters and toss. In a second bowl whisk together the reserved oyster liquor, chicken broth, eggs, and melted butter. Pour the mixture over the bowl and toss gently to moisten the cornbread cubes. Pour the mixture into your baking dish and bake, uncovered, for 30-35 minutes until golden brown.
SINGLE FRIED OYSTERS
1 pint freshly shucked raw oysters, 2 cups buttermilk, 1¼ cup fine yellow cornmeal, ¾ cup all-purpose flour, 1 tbsp Creole seasoning, 1 tsp kosher salt, 1 quart peanut oil. While the oil heats, pour the oysters into a colander or strainer and let them drain. Then, rinse with fresh water to wash off any debris or shell fragments. Pour the buttermilk into a medium-sized bowl and dunk the drained oysters. Let them marinate for 15 to 20 minutes. Place the cornmeal, flour, creole seasoning and salt in a shallow bowl or pie plate and whisk to combine. Remove the oysters from the buttermilk one at a time and dredge them in the cornmeal mixture. Toss gently and make sure they are well coated, then shake any excess bread off. Place the coated oysters on a metal cooling rack until all of them have been coated. Letting them sit for a few minutes helps to fuse the breading and buttermilk and keeps the breading from falling off when they are fried. Place a large stockpot, Dutch oven, or cast iron skillet with high sides over medium-high heat and add one to two inches of oil. When the oil reaches 370 degrees, carefully add the oysters, one at a time to fry. Depending on the size of your pan, it works best to fry in batches and only cook six to eight at a time. You do not want to crowd them. (Maintain a consistent heat of 370 degrees by increasing or decreasing the heat under the pan.)Let the oysters fry for about two to three minutes, stirring occasionally or until the breading is light golden brown and the meat is opaque with the edges slightly curled. Use a wire kitchen spider or slotted spoon to remove them from the oil. Place on a paper towel or wire cooling rack to drain. Repeat until all of the oysters are fried and serve immediately. Optional, garnish with fresh lemon or lime slices and serve with your choice of sauce and sides.

title: Maritime Museum hosts watermen's stories
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Maritime Museum hosts watermen's stories

 January 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Business 
 
 992
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — A crowd of 100 people gathered at the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum on Jan. 11 to hear story swaps from seven watermen.Big storms and big hauls were remembered, as were the regulations, cost of gas and Venezuelan crab meat that made net profits difficult.
These salty tales from yesterday were moderated by Brent Lewis.
This was a rock star moment for these men and one woman, who normally get up way before dawn and head out in the darkness to find oysters and crabs. The crowd listened attentively and often gave hearty laughs.
Waterman and politician George O'Donnell offered the age-old chestnut, "If you don't know how to cuss, you buy a work boat, and you will learn real fast."
The event was recorded for posterity by the museum at the Van Lennep Auditorium, and it was sponsored by the Upper Shore Regional Folklife Center. On top of the 100 guests present, there were another 30 on Zoom.
Being a waterman is tough. There is no job security. There is no health insurance. If they get injured, they are out of work, and there certainly is no pension or 401(k).
"If you wake up a watermen, every day you wake up with nothing all over again. You gotta be a welder, you gotta be a carpenter, you gotta be a mechanic, you gotta be a bookkeeper," O'Donnell said.
And yet there is a glimmer in the eyes of these watermen who love it.
The watermen speaking at the event included George O'Donnell, Calvert Thompson, Jeff Harrison, Rachel Fazenbaker, Eugene Austin, Joey Sadler and Troy Wilkins. From Miles River to Love Point to Harris Creek and many secret nooks on the Bay, they worked many different rivers on the Eastern Shore.
Sometimes there are big storms with 50 knots of wind and lightning. If you are out there, there is no place to hide, they said. More than one described the momentary blindness that comes after a big lightning strike out on the water.
The watermen shared the stories of times they thought they might not make it back to shore.
"I had a five gallon bucket, and I was bailing for all I could. The floor opened up and you could see where the gas had been at, but it was burning. Just flames, on top of the engine all the way to the canvas. It was a bad time for a few minutes there. I called up a friend and said, 'I have blowed up. I'm on fire' and he said, 'What?! What are you talking about?' He thought I was kidding. And then another boy up Mathews Creek he came along and towed me in after we got the fire out," Gene Austin said.
He continued, "I was sitting on the board, and I just started shaking. It just hit me. What had happened. To this day, I believe in guardian angels. When that heating block blowed up. I had a short sleeve shirt on and not one hair was burned," Austin said.
In sheer volume, the biggest waterman, Calvert Thompson, was nick named "Butterball." He had people in awe when he told the story of bailing out the cabin of a boat with five gallon buckets.
"There were 35 knot winds and seas were around 15 feet. We were early spring crabbin' in Cape Charles, Virginia. The tide ran so hard you couldn't see the buoys. You had to wait for the tide to slack up, and then you went as hard as you could go to fish your pots," Thompson said.
"And it was so rough that day that Raymond kept backing the boat up. We had scuppers in the back of the boat, when the water would come over the stern, it was just small holes in the back that would let water off of the gunnels. I had white boots on, and I had water over top of my boots from the floor up. I hollered up to the pilothouse and said, 'Raymond don't back up no more. Just sit. If he had backed up, we literally would have been gone. We were lucky."
One time when he was 23 or 24 years old, the engine died, so he stood on top of the cabin and threw the anchor as far as he could. Then he pulled the line in to move the boat. He said he went seven and half miles in two and a half hours until he was back home in Little Creek.
The one lady on the panel of watermen was Rachel Fazebaker. She could crack a joke and had the crowd going.
"When it starts blowing 20-25, I say bye boys," she said. "One time I was in five-foot seas and 30 mph winds and we were dredging. It completely unspooled, and we had to lower the boom. My knees were shaking the whole time. The captain taught me a lot that day and I said, 'I am not going out, not doing it. Not going out.' That captain taught me what not to do," she said.
As a 12-year-old, O'Donnell's mom would not let him crab out of Winchester Creek, where she could look out the window and make sure he was OK.
"Crabs were, number ones, were $8 a bushel. It was in my blood. It was all I knew. I was pretty much a capitalist, so once I found out you could make some money doing it, I kept doing it. That is all the incentive I needed, so when I went to the carnival, when I got where I could make five dollars a day, that was pretty good money," said O'Donnell.
The crowd oohed and ahhed with each story. When an hour had flown by, the master of ceremonies handed the microphone to the people in the crowd, who got to ask about five more questions, the most poignant being, "are you a dying breed?"
"Aren't there any young people doing this?"
The answer was sobering. The average age of a waterman now is 58.

title: Van Hollen discusses blue catfish, H-2B visas with Eastern Shore Delegation
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Van Hollen discusses blue catfish, H-2B visas with Eastern Shore Delegation

 January 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News

 ANNAPOLIS — During an Eastern Shore Delegation meeting Friday, U.S. Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-Md.) updated legislators on policy issues relating to the Eastern Shore that are "on the horizon."Van Hollen told Eastern Shore legislators that the issue of blue catfish, an invasive species in the Chesapeake Bay, has received a lot of attention in Congress.
"We know that we've got to deal with this invasive species," he said. "And probably the best way to deal with it is to eat our way out of it."
Along with U.S. Sen. Ben Cardin (D-Md.) and U.S. Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md. 1st), Van Hollen said that he has been working to make it so that blue catfish are inspected by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration — like other fish products in the country — rather than by the U.S Department of Agriculture.
Van Hollen said they are also trying to get additional funding for the prevention of more blue catfish in the Bay. He said a $750,000 grant for this was included in an appropriations bill that has been passed by the U.S. Senate but not yet passed by the U.S. House of Representatives.
Del. Jay Jacobs (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) voiced his concerns with the the U.S. Department of Commerce's recent rejection of the state's request for a "fishery resource disaster" declaration. The request was made to address the damages caused by blue catfish and northern snakeheads in the Bay.
"These fish are growing so fast, and they're so aggressive that by the time everybody sees the financial disaster, it may be too late," Jacobs said.
Jacobs told Van Hollen that he hopes Van Hollen can "keep the pressure on" in the Senate.
Van Hollen thanked Jacobs, saying he agreed with him about the risks and dangers of the invasive species.
"We are in the aftermath of the administration's decision on the disaster assistance," Van Hollen said to Jacobs. "We are going back to them. We may reach out to you and your colleagues to get some additional information as we circle back."
At the meeting, Van Hollen also spoke about H-2B visas, which are important for seafood processing companies in the state.
Van Hollen said that for fiscal year 2024, the number of these visas, which are for temporary nonagricultural workers, has increased to more than 130,000.
"The challenge remains that it's a lottery system," he said. "And that it's impossible to run a business with certainty if your labor depends on a lottery system."
To address this, Van Hollen and Cardin have introduced a bill that would exempt seafood processors from the H-2B annual worker cap. Van Hollen said that although the bill has bipartisan support, it also has bipartisan opposition.
"And so we are trying to work that through the system and address concerns that have been raised on both sides of the aisle," he said.
Van Hollen also spoke about infrastructure and the 2018 Farm Bill at the meeting Friday. He said $18 million has been secured for different projects on the Eastern Shore, including various infrastructure projects.
On the Farm Bill, Van Hollen said the Senate has extended the bill through September of this year. He said the bill has important provisions for farmers such as crop protection.

title: 'Plenty of shell'
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
'Plenty of shell'

 February 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 1066
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — In July, Maryland Gov. Wes Moore signed an executive order to establish an Oyster and Shell Substrate Task Force, created to develop a "proactive plan to keep and purchase oyster shells to ensure the state has enough hard surface to increase oyster abundance in the bay."This was tied in with another executive order of Moore's with the goal to create, "healthy watersheds that benefit the environment, the economy and communities."
Realizing a hearty oyster production creates cleaner water by filtering excess nutrients and sediments from the water, the task force now meets monthly. They discuss how to produce more oysters, transport oyster shells or talk about using alternative substrate in the water.
During their meeting on Jan. 18, Kent County Commission President Ron Fithian responded to Chesapeake Bay Foundation Executive Director Allison Colden.
In a previous meeting Colden said the seed and shell program, which lasted for 46 years, was reported to be a waste of the state's resources.
Fithian refuted that, having observed the success of Maryland's past oyster program, the Maryland Seed and Shell Program, from 1960-2006.
"There's no copy of such a report or any facts to back up her statement," he told the task force.
He drew from his history on the Eastern Shore, urging the members to not accept her research as fact.
Fithian stated during the 46 years of the seed and shell program, the state spent $48 million, planting 190 million bushels of shell. That averaged out to 4.2 million bushels per year. Maryland harvested approximately 60 million bushels of oysters with a dockside value estimated between $400 million to $1.2 billion.
Doing the math, Fithian said the program was "hardly a waste."
While he had their attention, he warned some groups deliberately deceive the public claiming there's not enough oyster shell in the Bay to place in the water — alternative sources are needed.
Fithian declared that false.
"The Bay is loaded with oyster shells from one end to the other."
He described the process. You find an area with shells with low oyster production and place them in productive areas.
Fithian pointed out there is a great supply of these shells at Man O'War Shoals in the upper bay. A 25-30 year supply even if Maryland decided to plant a million shell per year, he added.
"The transportation cost to the state, would be $2 or $4 a bushel."
But of late, he said, certain groups have taken away "twenty-five percent of the most productive oyster bottom from commercial fishers."
They build sanctuaries — areas where the wild harvest of oysters is prohibited, Fithian said.
Although, that may seem like a protective idea, it is not he told the task force.
Declaring an oyster bottom a "sanctuary," means oyster bars sit undisturbed. This does not lead to oyster production. Oysters cease production and die of old age, Fithian emphasized.
An inactive oyster bed invites filth too, said the commissioner.
"Oyster larvae needs a clean shell to attach itself. That's why areas still harvested will generally have a higher spat count (oyster larvae that attach to the shell) more than closed areas."
Fithian brought up Harris Creek as a prime example of going from an open seeding area to a sanctuary.
"During the seed and shell program, the state would place dredge shell in Harris Creek. Then mother nature would provide it with oyster larvae. Some years the spat count would be between 800-2,000 a bushel. Shells at a specific size, were transplanted to other areas, with a survival rate of 97 percent."
Since it was a highly successful spot, Fithian added, the Chesapeake Bay Foundation turned the area into a sanctuary thinking they'd also be a success.
Fithian called it a failed project.
"Spat count is less than 100 per bushel."
The site sits untouched, collecting sediment, making it unattractive for larvae.
He said the foundation was responsible.
"They supported spending $35 million and took the greatest natural oyster hatchery on the Bay and ruined it so it can never be a hatchery again."
Fithian posed a question to the task force, "What's more wasteful? $48 million to produce 60 million bushels of oysters over a 47 year span and a dockside value too large to count? Or $38 million for the Harris Creek project alone?".
Despite these comments, Fithian remarked he's not completely opposed to sanctuaries. They need to be created using the right substrate, he added.
This is not happening and those who are creating sanctuaries continue to repeat the same mistakes.
Mistakes leading to more pollution.
Fithian claimed the foundation applied for a permit to create three oyster reefs in Lynnhaven River. After they did, waterfront residents reported plastic and paper waste. Also the Virginia Institute of Marine Science found, "polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons."
He said that the foundation was ordered to remove all the junk at the bottom.
"Someone needs to explain to these government agencies the Chesapeake Bay is not a landfill. It's the greatest resource the state has and should be treated as such."
He challenged the task force with a call-to-action.
Stop spreading falsehoods about the lack of natural shell.
Allow the Department of Natural Resources to open up more areas.
Provide ample amounts of substrate needed for aquaculture, the oyster industry and restoration.
"Stop experimenting with far-fetched ideas that continue to fail time and time again."
After his remarks, Colden said she was taken aback, not expecting the commissioner to have so much time for a "soliloquy."
She said he wasted everyone's fifteen minutes and encouraged Fithian to look through her research, evidence of her claims, in a Google Drive she shared with the task force.
Later when Kent County News reached out to the Chesapeake Bay Foundation, concerning Fithian's comments, they offered this statement.
"The Oyster Shell and Substrate Task Force was created to identify ways to increase the number of oysters in Chesapeake Bay across all sectors — restoration, aquaculture, and the public fishery by addressing the shortage of oyster shell. It will take expertise and cooperation across all groups and stakeholders to create innovative and durable solutions to this challenging problem. CBF looks forward to serving an important role in the task force moving these conversations forward."
There's no argument that oyster production is good for water health. But there is an ongoing debate about the manner of which that happens, and who gets to decide what's best for the bay.
Chair of the Delmarva Fisheries Association, Rob Newberry, backing Fithian's statements, said his facts and figures can be found in Maryland Department of Natural Resources Shellfish Monitoring and Assessment Program.
The task force will continue to meet monthly at: https://go.activecalendar.com/doit-md/event/oyster-shell-and-substrate-taskforce-meeting-3/.

title: Mautz introduces oyster legislation
author: Connie Connolly
content:
Mautz introduces oyster legislation

 March 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly | Section: General Assembly 
 
 1221
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — State Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) introduced legislation last month to require the Maryland Department of Natural Resources to develop an updated fishery management plan for oysters and to allow DNR to alter the boundaries of "certain oyster sanctuaries.""SB 922 repeals onerous requirements which prevent the Department of Natural Resources from updating oyster management strategies for sanctuaries, aside from the large-scale restoration projects that are covered by federal regulations," Mautz said.
In addition, the legislation would allow watermen to dredge by powerboat in the "public oyster fishery area in Eastern Bay in Queen Anne's and Talbot counties."
"If there are areas that are conducive to power dredging, it's shown to be a phenomenal way to grow oysters and to restore the bottom, and it's proven time and time again," Mautz said.
The bill's co-sponsor is Sen. Jack Bailey (R-St. Mary's, Calvert) of southern Maryland. The bill is cross-filed with House Bill 1231, sponsored by Del. Chris Adams (R-Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico).
Mautz said in a Feb. 17 interview that he and Bailey introduced the legislation "to give the department the authority to adjust the boundaries on sanctuaries because the last five years of DNR's reporting on the status of sanctuaries is abysmal."
"Over half of them are dead. Some are doing okay, but most are failing or dead, meaning that oyster bars that used to be flourishing prior to the creation of the sanctuary (have) been covered over with silt and mud," Mautz said.
"The idea is that they need to be managed. They can't just be set aside," Mautz said. "That's why jokingly some will say oyster sanctuaries are like oyster cemeteries, because those used to be vibrant oyster grounds."
Opposition to the billAt an Education, Energy, and the Environment Committee hearing Feb. 27, Mautz's legislation was met with resistance by conservation leaders and officials from the Department of Natural Resources.
Opposing the legislation was Dr. Allison Colden, Maryland executive director with the Chesapeake Bay Foundation. She said nine areas of the Chesapeake Bay have experienced overfishing of oysters.
"If we continue to fish at these rates, we will locally cause those populations to go extinct," she said.
Mautz said "a lot of the work" the Chesapeake Bay Foundation does is "fantastic — their science is needed. However, we need management, and we need to grow oysters."
Touting the success of oyster sanctuaries, Colden said, "For the past two years, with these sanctuaries in place, the oyster fisheries enjoyed the highest harvest on record since the 1980s. Additionally, modeling from the University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science indicates that larval transport from these oyster sanctuaries does have the ability to contribute to harvest areas as we approach 2025."
The "federal and state investment," along "working with partners," in the "big five" sanctuaries has been "in the ballpark of $39 million," DNR Assistant Secretary for Aquatic Resources Kristen Fidler said. She called the efforts made in those sanctuaries a "massive success, and we're still studying all of the ramifications and just how they're impacting beneficially the larger ecosystem in the Bay."
Watermen support the billHowever, Mautz and watermen speaking in favor of the legislation to open oyster harvesting in sanctuaries said working the bottom to clear silt and sediment smothering the oysters contributes to the health of the population.
Jeff Harrison, president of the Talbot Watermen Association and a member of the Oyster Advisory Commission, testified at the hearing.
"We basically are looking to have the ability to be able to go into these areas," he said. "We're not talking about going out and catching oysters. We're talking about going in and putting something there."
Harrison suggested that watermen plant and harvest oysters on a four-year rotational basis. Broad Creek was the best tributary in the Bay because watermen did restoration work that cost $1 million "right alongside Harris Creek — (and it cost) $30 million."
"We did a much better job than what they did," he said. "So we're saying give us a chance to go into these failing sanctuaries and try to do something."
Robert T. Brown, president of the Maryland Watermen Association, said a group of sanctuaries on the western side of the Bay "has been ignored," forcing commercial oystermen to fish farther up the Bay.
"There has been no money set aside to rebuild (the area from the Patuxent River to Holland Point) or do anything with it," Brown said. "It is laying there and it is silty we can't work into it; we can't go in and cultivate it. We want to go into these places and plant spat on shell, wild seed, maybe dredging and bringing the shells up so we can get a natural spat set into it."
"The seed-on-shell program that once existed was a self-funding program," Mautz said. "It didn't take these millions and millions of dollars coming from taxpayers. That's a big part of the system that we need to take a serious look at and consider in making these decisions moving forward."
Jim Mullin with the Maryland Oystermen Association and a member of the Oyster Advisory Commission, testified in favor of the bill.
"We look to go into some of these areas, rehabilitate them with financing and our own infrastructure to … get them viable again, because otherwise they're just sitting there. He wants to address "these areas that are failing and bring them up to standard," he said.
Sen. Mary Beth Carozza (R-Somerset, Worcester, Wicomico) and a member of the EEE Committee said her expectation since 2019 and working with DNR was that sanctuaries would improve, but "we have basically dead oysters covered over."
"This is not the result that we were looking for," she said.
Problem with power dredgingDave Sikorski, executive director of Coastal Conservation Association Maryland, said his organization is "largely made up of recreational anglers," but attended the hearing "to advise and educate the public on the conservation of marine resources."
Citing his experience and credentials in the areas of sport fisheries and as a member of two oyster policy entities, he said he had a "very unique experience" to consider "what is most important for the public, what is most important for clean water and what is most important for recreational fishing."
Sikorski said power dredging removes living oysters, displaces shell and allows for spat set, "but it's important that we do consider things differently today than in the past."
"What hasn't changed is our understanding of destruction by power dredges," he said.
"I absolutely respect the watermen's perspective on that because they see it, but we must make sure we enfold this into the whole oyster management plan," he said.
Fidler said the "onerous requirements" Mautz wanted repealed was now a "moot point."
"We were unable to explore, evaluate and implement changes to sanctuary boundaries unless and until the oyster management plan had been developed and approved by the Oyster Advisory Commission, and then incorporated by reference into our own regulations as the fishery management plan," she said.
"And so now that we have done that, and the Oyster Advisory Commission introduced an amendment to that plan, which has been adopted and is being finalized now and going through the COMAR process to be incorporated by reference into our regulations that will allow us the ability to explore, evaluate and potentially implement changes to sanctuary boundaries," Fidler said.
"It's taken a little bit longer than we expected, but we do anticipate that to be all wrapped up here very shortly," Fidler said.

title: Talbot council considers $100,000 to oyster credit program
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Talbot council considers $100,000 to oyster credit program

 March 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 482

 Read News Document

 EASTON — At a Tuesday evening working session, the Talbot County Council discussed the potential to fund Oyster Nutrient Trading credits and reviewed draft cannabis legislation.The Talbot County Council is considering allocating $100,000 to the Talbot County Oyster Nutrient Credit Pilot Program. If approved, the council will allocate $500,000 over five years for the program.
Nutrient credit trading allows municipalities and businesses to meet water quality permit requirements using oysters' pollutant-filtering capabilities to remove nutrients from the water.
In 2016, the Chesapeake Bay Program approved the use of oysters as a best management practice for nutrient reduction requirements for aquaculture. This practice removes nitrogen and phosphorus through aquaculture and generates tradable credits.
Credits are generated when oysters are harvested from leased areas or public fisheries. The Maryland Department of Natural Resources verifies the harvest. Credits must be purchased in a 2:1 ratio to offset one pound of permitted pollution.
The program aims to plant oysters through the public fishery pilot to generate credits starting in year three. The county could use this program to offset agricultural pollution.
The $100,000 would initially fund two parts of the oyster nutrient credit program: the post-harvest credits from aquaculture leases and a new public fishery pilot program.
Post-harvest credits involve purchasing credits already generated when oysters are harvested from leased areas. The pilot program would include investing in planting oysters in designated public oyster bars normally open to fishing.
The allocations between these two programs must be determined in consultation with the County Council. If funds are allocated, it will support local watermen and generate credits that could offset pollution from other sources like agriculture.
CANNABIS
The council reviewed the state's limits on cultivation, processing and dispensary cannabis licenses. Patrick Thomas, county attorney, emphasized that cannabis dispensaries in Talbot County must not be unduly burdensome on cannabis businesses.
The council reviewed draft legislation about cannabis and the changes made by the county.
The council added language to regulate the zoning distance between dispensaries and preexisting schools, child care centers, places of worship, libraries, public parks and other similar buildings. Dispensaries would need to be at least 500 feet from these locations. This was not originally in state law but was added in the county ordinance.
There were distance restrictions for other dispensaries to be at least 1,000 feet — or just under a quarter mile — from each other.
Thomas noted a pending state bill that, if passed, may change the distance restrictions applied to dispensaries. House Bill 805 will alter the distance restrictions applicable to a licensed cannabis dispensary. If this bill passes, the required distance between dispensaries could change from 500 feet to 2,000 feet.
Thomas told the council that they are waiting until after April 8 to incorporate changes from the state legislative session into the county's proposed cannabis zoning bill. The state legislative session is scheduled to adjourn on April 8, so the county may better align with any relevant changes to the state law.

title: Local religious leaders pray for prosperity in upcoming crab, clam, fishing seasons at Blessing of the Fleet
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Local religious leaders pray for prosperity in upcoming crab, clam, fishing seasons at Blessing of the Fleet

 April 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 345

 TILGHMAN — On April 7, local religious leaders gathered with the watermen community to pray for a blessing of safety and prosperity for the upcoming crab, clam and fishing seasons.The St. John's Chapel sponsored the annual Blessing of the Fleet ceremony at the Dogwood Harbor in Tilghman.
Rev. Linda Haddaway King led the ceremony, acknowledging the history behind the Blessing of the Fleet. King described the rich history of boat builders in Tilghman, returning to the early settlement in the 1840s and upholding mastery today.
David McQuay, a lifelong boat builder, was awarded for his decades of master boat building and for preserving the craft. Jeannie Haddaway-Riccio, daughter of the late Herman Hardaway, a former boat builder, presented McQuay with a citation from the governor.
In her speech, she highlighted her childhood, shaped by the boat-building community.
"It was symbolic of a community coming together and helping each other out, and that doesn't happen everywhere," Haddaway-Riccio said. "We are so fortunate that in Talbot County we still have that community spirit."
State Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) presented McQuay with a citation from the Maryland Senate. Mautz read the citation that gave its sincerest congratulations in recognition of the remarkable talent and skill that McQuay had shared during his lifetime and the benefit it provided the community.
State Rep. Christopher Adams (R-Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) followed and presented McQuay with a lifetime achievement certificate for all his boat-building years.
The Bay Hundred Men then sang songs from "America the Beautiful" to "Wade in the Water" before local clergy prayed for the fleet's blessing.
Rev. Rob King then read a poem to the crowd about his appreciation for the watermen community.
King led the crowd in a final prayer before the blowing of the shofar, a musical horn fashioned from a ram's horn.
"When you blow the shofar, it announces God's presence," King said. "And that's what we want for all of you — God's presence in that boat with you to begin the waters — because we can't do a thing without our God, and the Lord will make Himself known to you."

 The Maryland Agricultural and Resource-Based Industry Development Corporation is once again offering its Maryland Watermen's Microloan Program to assist "generational watermen" with the purchase of needed equipment via low-interest, unsecured loans.An advantage of this loan program is that if all payments are made as agreed to by the borrower, MARBIDCO will forgive a portion of these payments towards the end of the loan agreement, according to a press release about the program.
"With the support of Maryland's Governor and General Assembly, changes were made to MARBIDCO's Maryland Watermen's Microloan Program during the recent legislative session to better serve the commercial watermen community with the inclusion of the Potomac River Fisheries Commission licensed fishermen and the potential raising of the maximum loan amounts," said MARBIDCO Executive Director Steve McHenry.
Previously, Maryland law limited the loans made under this program to a range of $7,000 to $15,000. The new law provides more flexibility in this regard, the MARBIDCO release said. The interest rate charged for a loan made under this program is 3%.
Beginning July 1, the program expanded to include watermen holding commercial fishing licenses issued by the Potomac River Fisheries Commission. In addition, the MARBIDCO Board of Directors has recently increased the maximum loan amount available under the program from $15,000 to $20,000 for equipment purchases, up to $30,000 for the purchase of a workboat, and up to $40,000 for the purchase of both a workboat and equipment. The minimum loan amount remains at $7,000.
Under Maryland law, a generational waterman is a licensed commercial waterman who can demonstrate that 50% or more of the waterman's annual income was derived from commercial seafood harvesting. The law further provides that two years of the most recent federal income tax returns must be submitted with an application. The waterman must hold a TFL license from the Department of Natural Resources, or a commercial license to catch finfish, crabs, clams, and oysters, issued by the Potomac River Fisheries Commission. The applicant must also have a minimum credit score of 620.
The State Budget included $500,000 for the microloan program in FY 2025.

title: Memories of crab catching adventures
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking

Memories of crab catching adventures

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: News

 My grandson Mason has been spending some time down on Tangier Island this summer. Mason has been telling me all about the crab cakes and steamed crabs he's been eating fresh out of the water and right into the steamer.Mason's brings back memories of the 1950s and 1960s adventures of crabbing. Mom would back the pickup out, and we would load the supplies, which included baskets with inner tubes attached to help the baskets float, chicken necks for bait, heavy string to tie the hook and sinker to, crab nets, towels, a picnic basket with sandwiches and a big jug of water.
We loaded up and rode in the back of the truck so we could hoot and holler at our friends as we rode through town. Our destination would be one of two country landings with docks for crabbing and areas for swimming.
The first was Mumford's Landing down off St, Martin's Neck Road (now a development off the Route 90 bridge outside of Ocean City), and the second was a dock called Little Georgetown, just down the road from our farm on the Delaware side.
One particular day, we were headed to Mumford's Landing. Upon arriving, Mom picked a spot to tie our strings on the dock poles. We took the lines and hung the nuts, bolts and sinkers on the bottom so the weight held the line down. Then we tied on the chicken neck for bait.
You had a choice — go swimming now or later — but you had to move down a good distance to stay away from the baited lines. Mom got two baskets ready with inner tubes to float the baskets, grabbed a crab net and walked along the shoreline crabbing. Someone stayed back with another net and basket to gradually pulled up the lines, placing the neck under the line to catch the falling crabs.
Upon arriving at home, the still kicking crabs were unloaded, the fire started and the Old Bay seasoning was pulled out. Once the crabs were bright orange/reddish in color the fire was pulled away and the crabs pulled and placed on the picnic tables to be picked.
Of course, we ate the delicious meat until we were full, and then we put it in containers to be carried to the kitchen to be made into dishes such as crab cakes, crab soup and much more.
You can purchase crabs locally at LNT Seafood in Preston, Blough's Seafood outside of Denton, Kool Ice and Seafood in Cambridge, Kayla's crabs in Federalsburg on Preston Rd, Trident Seafood on Rt 50 IN Hebron and Fat Boys Seafood on Old Ocean City Road in Salisbury. There are many other small local spots featuring fresh seafood catches, but trust "word of mouth" for the best recommendations.
CRAB DIP8 ounces crab meat, 8 ounces cream cheese (softened), 1/2 cup sour cream, 2 tbsp mayonnaise, 1 tbsp lemon juice, 1 1/4 tsp Worcestershire sauce, 1/2 tsp dry mustard, 1/4 cup shredded cheddar cheese, 1 pinch garlic salt (optional), 2 tsp Old Bay seasoning or JO seasoning.
In a large bowl, mix cream cheese, sour cream, mayonnaise, lemon juice, Worcestershire sauce and dry mustard until smooth. Stir in 2 tbsp of shredded cheddar cheese. Add crab meat into the mixture. Pour mixture into a 1-quart casserole dish. Top with remaining cheese, or more. But not too much because you don't want the cheese to overtake the taste of the crab. Add some of your favorite crab or seafood seasoning on top. Bake at 325 degrees for about 30 minutes or until the top is browned.
CRAB MAC N CHEESE1 16 oz box dry Cavatappi pasta or elbows, 1 lb jumbo lump crab meat, ½ cup unsalted butter, ½ cup all-purpose flour, 1 ½ tsp seafood seasoning such as Old Bay or JO, ½ tsp garlic salt, ½ tsp ground mustard, ¼ tsp black pepper, 2 oz chive & onion cream cheese (softened), 5 cups whole milk, 5 cups shredded cheddar and Monterey jack cheese (divided). For the topping: 2 tbsps unsalted butter (melted), ½ cup panko breadcrumbs, 1 tbsp grated parmesan, ¼ tsp seafood seasoning, 1 tbsp chopped fresh Italian parsley.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Spray a 13-by-9-inch baking dish with cooking spray. Set aside. Cook the pasta in salted water per the package directions until al dente. Drain well and set aside. Pick over the crab meat removing any shells and cartilage. Set aside. In a medium-size heavy bottomed saucepan, melt ½ cup butter over medium heat. To the melted butter add flour, 1 ½ teaspoon seafood seasoning, garlic salt, ground mustard and black pepper. Mix until the flour has been absorbed by the butter stirring constantly. Whisk in the milk. Whisk constantly to prevent clumping. Bring the milk to a boil then immediately lower the heat to low. Simmer for 3-5 minutes gently bubbling and stirring to prevent sticking. Turn off the heat. Add cream cheese to the sauce. Stir until melted then add 3 cups of Borden shredded Cheddar and Monterey Jack cheese. Remove from the heat, stirring until melted. Add the cooked pasta and crab meat to a large mixing bowl. Pour the cheese sauce over and mix until fully coated and the crab meat is evenly distributed. Pour ½ into the baking dish. Top with 1 cup shredded cheese. Repeat with macaroni then top with the final 1 cup of shredded cheese. Topping: Melt 2 tablespoon butter in a small microwave safe bowl.. Mix with the panko bread crumbs, Parmesan cheese, and ¼ teaspoon seafood seasoning, Sprinkle on top. Place into the oven and bake for 30-40 minutes or until the top is golden and the edges are bubbly. Garnish with chopped parsley just before serving.
CHICKEN, CRAB, SAUSAGE GUMBO1 cup bacon grease, 3 tbsps olive oil, 1 yellow onion (chopped), 1 red bell pepper (chopped), 2 cups andouille sausage (sliced), 1 cup all-purpose flour, 4-6 cloves garlic (minced), 3/4 gallon chicken stock, 1 15-oz can chopped tomatoes, 1 tsp apple cider vinegar, 2 cups stewed and shredded chicken, 3 tbsps fresh parsley, 1 tbsp dried basil, 1 tbsp dried oregano, 2 cups frozen okra, 2 cups crab meat, salt, white pepper, lemon juice and Tabasco to taste, shopped green onions and rice.
Add 3 tablespoons olive oil or bacon grease to a cast-iron skillet and cook the onion and bell pepper until soft and set aside. Cook the sausage in the same skillet until browned and set aside with the vegetables. Add1 cup of the bacon grease to the skillet over medium heat and stir in the flour. Lower the heat to low and cook for at least 1 hour, stirring every 5 minutes. The roux should be thick, but not chalky. When it is dark tan and smells like toasted nuts, it is done. In a large stock pot or Dutch oven, add the sautéed vegetables and sausage, and heat over medium high heat. Add the garlic and simmer for 2 minutes. Add stock, tomatoes, vinegar, chicken and all other dry ingredients. Simmer on low to medium heat for at least 1 hour. Add salt, white pepper, lemon juice and Tabasco to taste. Skim off about 3 cups of liquid from the pot (with as few solids as possible) and combine in a bowl with about 1 cup roux. Stir until it thickens and becomes paste-like. Add about half this mixture back to the pot on low heat. Stir well. Let simmer for a few minutes and add more roux mixture to thicken or water or stock to thin. The gumbo should be thick, but not as thick as gravy. Add half of the okra. Simmer on very low for at least 30 minutes. Be careful, as it can easily burn. Add the remaining cup of okra and the crab meat 5 minutes before serving. Taste again for salt, white pepper, lemon juice and Tabasco. Serve in bowls with rice and garnish with green onion.
CHESAPEAKE CIOPPINO2 tbsps unsalted butter, 1 tbsp olive oil, 1/2 cup celery, (medium diced), 1 cup onion (medium diced), 1/2 cup fennel (thin sliced), 2 tbsps garlic (thin sliced or minced), 1 tbsp Old Bay or JO seasoning, 1 bay leaf, 1/2 tsp oregano, 1/4 tsp crushed red pepper, 1/4 tsp Worcestershire sauce, 2 cups chicken stock, 3 cups tomato puree, 1/2 lemon (sliced), 1 lb shrimp, 1 lb Maryland blue crab meat, 12 oysters (shucked), 1 lb rock fish (cut into large cubes), 24 mussels (cleaned or frozen).
Combine butter and olive oil in a medium stock pot. Heat on medium until butter has melted. Add celery, onion, garlic and fennel to the stock pot. Sauté until onion has become translucent, add crab seasoning, oregano, crushed red pepper, and Worcestershire sauce. Bring to a boil for 5 minutes, add chicken stock and tomato puree. Bring to a boil, reduce heat to low, cover and simmer for 30 minutes, Add the sliced lemon, shrimp, whole crab meat, oysters, rock fish and mussels, staggering to accommodate for cook times. Cover and simmer for 5 minutes or until mussels have opened. Serve hot.
MARYLAND CREME OF CRAB SOUP1/4 cup butter, 1 medium onion (coarsely chopped),1/3 cup flour, 4 cups milk or half-and-half, 1 tbsp Old Bay or JO seasoning, 1/2 tsp parsley flakes, 1 lb lump crab meat.
Melt butter in a three-quart saucepan on medium heat. Add onion; cook and stir 5 minutes or until softened. Add flour, Old Bay or JO, and parsley; whisk until well blended. While whisking constantly, gradually add milk. Bring just to boil. Stir in crabmeat. Reduce heat to low; simmer for 20 minutes stirring occasionally. Sprinkle with additional Old Bay or JO if desired.
To end this week, I'd like to send a special hello to Mr. Alan Planner and Mrs. Darlene Planner of Federalsburg. Thank you for being loyal readers and great friends.

Watermen harvested 430,000 bushels of Maryland oysters

 The Maryland Department of Natural Resources estimates that over 430,000 bushels of oysters were harvested commercially in Maryland from Oct. 1 to March 31. This was the fifth season in the past 30 years when the harvest surpassed 400,000 bushels."Maryland's oyster population has notably improved in recent years," said Department of Natural Resources Shellfish Division Director Christopher Judy. "This season's harvest far exceeded the average yield over the last several decades."
The preliminary harvest numbers are based on Maryland seafood dealer buy tickets. The estimated dockside value of this year's oyster harvest is $15 million, with an average dockside price per bushel of $35.
Limited market demand partially disadvantaged the '23-24 oyster season's success, which pushed watermen to keep their boats tied up several days a week. In the past two seasons, when the harvests exceeded 700,000 and 500,000 bushels, oystermen were working and delivering product to the shucking houses virtually every day.
Another factor at play was oyster abundance. This season, there were generally fewer oysters in the population available for harvest than in the prior two seasons.
Oyster abundance is strongly affected by spat set, the quantity of newly-attached juvenile oysters growing on existing shells. Strong sets yield a robust population several years later. Low sets yield a lower population.
The very strong spat set of 2020 helped produce the recent high harvests of 500,000 and 700,00 bushels, but the lower spat sets of 2021 and 2022 offered a lower abundance of market oysters for the fishery currently.
Most recently, the 2023 Fall Oyster Survey recorded a high spat set, spread across a broader geographic area than usual for Maryland. "With the right environmental conditions, the notably widespread spat set from last summer could bode well for future harvests," Judy said.
All sectors of Maryland's oyster management efforts are experiencing growth. The 2023-24 season saw a record yield of oysters from shellfish aquaculture operations and many oyster sanctuaries are showing promising signs of recovery.

Jack Brooks of the J.M. Clayton Company of Cambridge was named Advocate of the Year for his unparalleled work in protecting Maryland's seafood industry and the watermen who depend upon it for their livelihood.
As president of the J.M. Clayton Company, established by his great-grandfather in 1890, Brooks has a five-generation commitment to sourcing and advancing Chesapeake Bay seafood.

Crab for the luncheon crab cakes was supplied by the J.M Clayton Company.
The Oyster Recovery Partnership was recognized as the Nonprofit of the Year. For over 30 years, ORP's mission has been to restore the Bay's native oyster population by building sanctuary reefs, rebuilding public fishery reefs, supporting the aquaculture industry, recycling oyster shells, and public involvement through hands-on volunteering and events, according to executive director Ward Slacum.
Since it's founding in 1994, ORP has planted more than 11.5 billion oysters on 3,000 acres of reef and recycled more than 300,000 bushels of shell, Slacum said. Presenting the recognition, former Gov. Robert Ehrlich credited nonpartisan oyster restoration advocacy as one of the most successful aspects of his administration.
Steve Phillips of Phillips Seafood was recognized as Philanthropist of the Year.
Growing up working the waters of the Chesapeake Bay with his grandfathers developed Phillips' love for local watermen catching seafood for Maryland restaurants everyday, he said.
Recognizing "nothing in the world is better than fresh Maryland crab," Phillips worked to introduce Asian crab to provide more opportunities for crab cuisine year round in the wake of high demand.
As CEO of Phillips Seafood, Phillips has donated over $70,000 to the Maryland Watermen's Association to protect the heritage and future of commercial watermen in Maryland. Phillips Seafood also provides shells for the ORP's oyster reef rebuilding efforts. According to Jim Purdue of Perdue Farms presenting the award, Phillips represented "People who care when people aren't looking."

Currently President of the Talbot County Watermen Association, Harrison is a member of the ORP board, has served on the Oyster Advisory Commission and has often been called upon to testify on waterman-related legislative issues.
Harrison can regularly be found in his element of shucking oysters at countless community fundraising and public education events.
Harrison credited a love of the Bay as why he does what he does and strives to a time when the Bay was pristine, "and crabs were $3 a dozen," he said.
Harrison continues his work for a sense of empowerment for himself and others and progress for future generations.
Recognizing exemplary students pursuing cancer research, this year's Chesapeake Charities Cancer Research Scholarship was awarded to Alexandra Vlk, a fourth-year medical student in the Medical Scientists Training Program at the University of Maryland School of Medicine. Earning her PhD in innate immunology in 2023, Vlk is currently interviewing for pathology residency programs with the goal to become a compassionate pathologist and further develop cancer research.
