title: Appreciating local oysters
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Appreciating local oysters

 February 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1715
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Having grown up on the Eastern Shore, the oyster has been a much-appreciated seafood in my life.My mother made some of the greatest tasting oyster fritters on the Mason Dixon line. There are no watermen in my family, but we lived close enough to the water to respect the life of the waterman and the delicious delicacies that were a result of their hard work.
In our local area here, the most popular oyster varieties include Malpeques, Well Fleet, Blue Points, Delaware Bay, Chesapeake Bay, Chincoteagues, Apalachicola Bay and Gulf Coast.
East Coast oysters range from slightly salty to sharp salt flavor (Chesapeake, Delaware and Gulf Coast oysters have a light salt taste; all others have a sharper salty taste).
The Chesapeake Bay has been home to oystering since the early 19th century. Chesapeake Bay skipjacks are the last commercial sailing vessels in the United States.
The dredge boats once numbered in the thousands. Today only about a dozen or so remain.
Skip jacks are limited to 150 bushels of oysters daily. The dredging season runs from November through March 1. The recent ice has made it impossible for the boats to get out to perform their work — cutting into the ice and cutting into the pockets of our waterman and their families. Check your local newspapers and the Facebook posts of local fire departments, churches and organizations with upcoming oyster dinners and roast coming up for their fundraising events.
I know that many seafood markets are featuring fresh oysters in the shell or by the pint and quarts or opened for you. I like to open my own — eating them on the half shell or cooking them fresh.
Try going down to the docks and getting them from the waterman themselves. Support a trade that is slowly leaving our Eastern Shore. Thank a waterman who goes out in all kinds of weather laboring in a trade they must love that is full of obstacles. The weather has cleared, and the watermen are returning to the trade they love. I am on the way to the docks for oysters to prepare some of my favorite seafood dishes.
EASTERN SHORE OYSTER FRITTERSDrain 1 quart of oysters, reserving the juice, and set aside. Beat 2 eggs, add the reserved juice to the egg and add Worcestershire sauce to taste. Add 1 1/2 cups flour with 1 1/2 tsps baking powder and mix well. Add the oysters and lightly mix. Fry in hot oil, browning on both sides. Drain on a paper towel and serve warm. When dropping the fritters in the oil, make sure you have at least 3 oysters to a fritter.
TRADITIONAL MARYLAND OYSTER STEWIn a large saucepan, cook one-pint fresh shucked oysters, with juice, over low heat until edges begin to curl. Add 1 quart of milk, 1/4 cup butter, salt and pepper to taste. You can sprinkle some Old Bay seasoning on top if desired slowly, but do not boil. Serve hot with oyster crackers if desired.
SCALLOPED OYSTERSIn a greased two-quart casserole, place alternate layers of oysters and fresh cracker crumbs, doting each layer with butter. For this process you will need one quart of oysters with liquid, 2 to 3 cups fresh crushed crackers and 1/2 cup butter or 1 stick margarine. You can also sprinkle each layer with salt and pepper to taste. End with a layer of crumbs, and pour one to two cups of milk over the top. Dot the top with remaining butter or margarine and bake at 350 degrees until browned, about 40 to 50 minutes. Makes 6 generous servings.
OYSTER POT PIEIn a large saucepan place 5 or 6 diced potatoes, cleaned and peeled, with 5 or 6 carrots, 2 to 3 cleaned and diced onions, 1/2 pound of chopped ham, and 4 strips of uncooked bacon. Cook until done and add salt and pepper to taste. Sprinkle with 1/2 tsp parsley flakes and 1/2 tsp oregano. Mix 1 pint crushed tomatoes and the liquor of one pint of oysters. Add this to the already cooked ingredients. Bring to a boil; thicken with some cornstarch. When thick, add one pint of oysters. Cook until the oysters have curled edges. Pour into a baking dish lined with your favorite crust and place a crust over the top. Slightly prick the top crust with a fork, bake at 400 degrees until brown. This is so delicious for supper on a wintry day.
BACON OYSTER LETTUCE TOMATO1 cup all-purpose flour, 1 cup cornmeal, 1 tbsp garlic powder, 1 tbsp onion powder, 1/4 tsp cayenne pepper, Kosher salt, freshly ground pepper, 2 dozen oysters (freshly shucked), 12 slices thick-cut bacon, vegetable oil (for frying; about 5 cups), 8 slices brioche or white sandwich bread toasted, mayonnaise, bibb lettuce, and sliced tomatoes. Whisk flour, cornmeal, garlic powder, onion powder, and cayenne in a medium bowl; season with salt and pepper. Working in batches, toss oysters in flour mixture, transfer to a plate. Working in batches, cook bacon in a large skillet, preferably cast iron, over medium heat until crisp, 10–12 minutes per batch; drain on paper towels. Pour oil into a skillet with bacon fat to a depth of one inch and heat over medium-high heat until oil bubbles immediately when a pinch of cornmeal mixture is added. Working in batches, fry oysters, turning occasionally, until golden brown and crisp, about four minutes. Drain on paper towels, season with salt and pepper. Build sandwiches with mayonnaise, lettuce, tomatoes, bacon and fried oysters and serve.
OYSTER CORNBREAD STUFFING8 tbsps unsalted butter (divided), 4 stalks celery (finely chopped), 1/2 yellow onion (finely chopped), 1 tsp kosher salt, 1 tsp rubbed sage, 1 tsp dried rosemary, 1 tsp dried thyme, 1/2 tsp coarse ground black pepper, 6 cups cornbread cubes, 18 ounces oysters (chopped, liquor reserved), 2 cups chicken broth, 2 large eggs.
Preheat oven to 350 degrees and spray a 9-by-13-inch baking dish with vegetable oil spray. Add 4 tbsps unsalted butter to a large skillet on medium heat. Add in the celery and onions, cook for 6-8 minutes until translucent. Add in the salt, sage, rosemary, thyme, and black pepper and stir. To a large bowl add the cornbread cubes, vegetable mixture, and oysters and toss. In a second bowl whisk together the reserved oyster liquor, chicken broth, eggs, and melted butter. Pour the mixture over the bowl and toss gently to moisten the cornbread cubes. Pour the mixture into your baking dish and bake, uncovered, for 30-35 minutes until golden brown.
GRILLED OYSTERS WITH BACON AND CAYENNE BUTTER3 slices hickory-smoked or applewood-smoked bacon cut crosswise into 1/2-inch-wide strips, 1 cup unsalted butter cut into 1/2-inch cubes, 4 garlic cloves (peeled), 1 1/2 tbsps chopped fresh Italian parsley, 1 ½ tbsps chopped fresh cilantro, 1/2 tsp cayenne pepper, 1/2 tsp freshly ground black pepper, 1/2 tsp coarse kosher salt, 2 tbsps fresh lemon juice, 24 freshly shucked oysters on the half shell.
Prepare butter compound at least 2 hours ahead of time to give it time to firm. Cook bacon in a heavy medium skillet over medium heat until crisp. Using a slotted spoon, transfer bacon to the processor. Add butter, garlic, Italian parsley, cayenne pepper, black pepper, and 1/2 tsp coarse salt. Blend until smooth, occasionally scraping down sides of bowl. With the machine running, gradually add fresh lemon juice and continue to process until blended. Place a large sheet of waxed paper on the work surface. Drop butter by heaping tbspfuls onto paper in a long log. Using paper as aid, shape butter into a 2-inch-diameter log. Wrap to enclose; chill butter until firm, at least 2 hours. Prepare barbecue (medium-high heat). Spread 1/2-inch-thick layer of rock salt on a large, rimmed baking sheet. Place the baking sheet on a grill rack and heat for 20 minutes. Cut 24 1/8- to 1/4-inch-thick rounds from cayenne-butter log. Transfer the hot baking sheet from the grill to a heat proof surface. Nestle oysters in hot rock salt. Top each oyster with a slice of cayenne butter. Return the baking sheet with oysters to grill. Close the grill and cook until butter melts and start to brown, 6 to 8 minutes. Spoon a shallow layer of additional rock salt onto each of 6 plates. Nestle four grilled oysters in salt on each plate and serve.
SINGLE FRIED OYSTERS1 pint freshly shucked raw oysters, 2 cups buttermilk, 1¼ cup fine yellow cornmeal, ¾ cup all-purpose flour, 1 tbsp Creole seasoning, 1 tsp kosher salt, 1 quart peanut oil. While the oil heats, pour the oysters into a colander or strainer and let them drain. Then, rinse with fresh water to wash off any debris or shell fragments. Pour the buttermilk into a medium-sized bowl and dunk the drained oysters. Let them marinate for 15 to 20 minutes. Place the cornmeal, flour, creole seasoning and salt in a shallow bowl or pie plate and whisk to combine. Remove the oysters from the buttermilk one at a time and dredge them in the cornmeal mixture. Toss gently and make sure they are well coated, then shake any excess bread off. Place the coated oysters on a metal cooling rack until all of them have been coated. Letting them sit for a few minutes helps to fuse the breading and buttermilk and keeps the breading from falling off when they are fried. Place a large stockpot, Dutch oven, or cast iron skillet with high sides over medium-high heat and add one to two inches of oil. When the oil reaches 370 degrees, carefully add the oysters, one at a time to fry. Depending on the size of your pan, it works best to fry in batches and only cook six to eight at a time. You do not want to crowd them. (Maintain a consistent heat of 370 degrees by increasing or decreasing the heat under the pan.)Let the oysters fry for about two to three minutes, stirring occasionally or until the breading is light golden brown and the meat is opaque with the edges slightly curled. Use a wire kitchen spider or slotted spoon to remove them from the oil. Place on a paper towel or wire cooling rack to drain. Repeat until all of the oysters are fried and serve immediately. Optional, garnish with fresh lemon or lime slices and serve with your choice of sauce and sides.

title: With crab season open, Talbot watermen tracking weather and economy

With crab season open, Talbot watermen tracking weather and economy

 April 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 EASTON — As Maryland's blue crab season begins, local watermen have their eyes on the weather — and the economy.Jeff Harrison, president of the Talbot Watermen Association, said last week that he's expecting this year's crabbing outlook to be fair, perhaps slightly better than last year.
Harrison said some crabbing diehards on the Eastern Shore found success in the first few days after the season officially opened April 1.
"When they wake up, they're hungry. That's when you tend to catch most of them, is when they first wake up," Harrison said.
But recent cold temperatures slowed that early success. Harrison said it's now a "waiting game" as temperatures warm up and June nears, the start of what he calls the prime season for crabbing, which runs through September.
Harrison says the Watermen Association's main concern this year is the economy.
"We are in Maryland, where a lot of government workers have been laid off," he said. "Those are the people that buy our crabs more than likely, and so that's kind of the concern that we might have."
Harrison added that similar economic concerns have been prominent in oyster markets on the Eastern Shore since the pandemic, which changed the restaurant businesses landscape.
Last week, Harrison said crabs began selling for around $150 per bushel off the boat. He says that price will likely increase in May.
The 2025 Blue Crab Winter Dredge Survey hasn't been released yet by the Department of Natural Resources, but 2024's survey showed Maryland's crab population at 317 million. It suffered a drastic drop from 594 million in 2019 to 227 million in 2022, before rebounding to 323 million a year later and remaining steady last year.
Harrison noted decreases in small crabs is a concern. The juvenile crab population, per the DNR, was observed at 86 million in 2021, down 73% in a two-year span. The number rebounded to 138 million in 2024.
"They have been seeing not as many. We did have an increase last year," Harrison said. "I think you'll see an increase this year."
STATE REGULATIONS
The crab season in the Chesapeake Bay runs from April 1 to Dec. 15.
In April and from October to Dec. 15, catching crabs is allowed in rivers, creek and tributaries a half-hour after sunrise until sunset. In May through September, it's allowed a half-hour before sunrise until sunset.
In the Bay itself, in April and from October to Dec. 15, crabbing is permitted a half-hour after sunrise until 5 p.m. In May through September, it's allowed a half-hour before sunrise until 5 p.m.
Those looking to use trotlines, collapsible traps, net rings, seines or eel pots must acquire a license from the Department of Natural Resources. Unlicensed individuals can use handlines and dip nets, as well as up to two registered crab pots on private property.
The state sets bag and size limits for unlicensed and licensed individuals. For complete information on those limits and all blue crab regulations, visit dnr.maryland.gov/fisheries/pages/regulations/blue-crab.aspx.

title: Planned salmon farm's discharge permit challenged in Cecil County court
author: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com

Planned salmon farm's discharge permit challenged in Cecil County court

 April 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com | Section: Business

 ELKTON — The Chesapeake Bay Foundation has filed a petition for judicial review in Cecil County Circuit Court against AquaCon, the Norwegian company that plans to build a land-based salmon farming operation at the Bainbridge Development Corporation property in Port Deposit.According to CBF, there are concerns about the Maryland Department of the Environment's discharge permit, which would allow AquaCon to send 1.9 million gallons of post-production water back into the Susquehanna River daily. Paul Small, CBF Vice President for Litigation, pointed to similar companies in Florida and Canada that have not had the best results on the native habitat, with reports of fish kills in North America and fires and potential water contamination in Denmark.
"Land-based salmon farms are relatively new and unpredictable," Small said. "Knowing the prior failures of these types of plants, and that the Susquehanna River is already overloaded with nutrient pollution, MDE's permit must protect against these risks."
In court papers, CBF noted that the company modeled its discharge permit paperwork after a similar operation in Maine that — to date — has not begun production or its permits have expired.
AquaCon, based in Oslo, Norway, announced last August that it plans to build its Recirculating Aquaculture System (RAS) facility on 160 acres of the former US Navy training base where it would draw water from the Susquehanna, grow salmon in large indoor pools and sell the fish to wholesalers and the restaurant industry.
Toni Sprenkle, Executive Director of BDC, was excited that the first tenant of the property had been announced. She was assured that there would be no environmental impacts.
"This is a very good use for Bainbridge," Sprenkle said in August. "There are unique attributes with this. It's close to the Susquehanna River so it can pull large amounts of water."She added that the company recycles and treats that water on site and when it is finally discharged it would "come out cleaner than it went in."
CBF begs to differ. In the court documents, the foundation argues that not enough is known about the science of these operations, pointing the fragility of the river and the harm that could come with discharges of nitrogen, phosphorous and sediment. This could mean the degradation of oxygen levels, grasses and impact recreational and commercial fishermen as well as hunters.
"The Susquehanna River is already overloaded with nitrogen and sediment pollution that runs off of farms and suburban developments," said Gussie Maguire, CBF Maryland Staff Scientist. "While we have made tremendous progress reducing that pollution, development pressure continues to strain the health of our waterways. MDE must adequately consider this risk for new, experimental projects like AquaCon."
Just before being released to market, these salmon are moved to purge tanks where they will slough a protein that — if left in place — would make the fish unpalatable. That protein, geosmin, is not included in the discharge permit, according to CBF.
The discharge permit requires the company to have net-zero discharge. However, it allows AquaCon to purchase credits to offset the amount of its nitrogen, phosphorous and sediment.
AquaCon had plans to build its RAS plant in Caroline County but residents of the Federalsburg community fought back claiming the plant would endanger the Atlantic sturgeon population in Marshyhope Creek. In October 2022, AquaCon agreed and withdrew its pending Maryland Department of the Environment discharge permit application. Sprenkle pointed out that Marshyhope Creek is a smaller body of water.

title: Eastern Shore resident advocates for sustainable seafood on Capitol Hill
author: Lily Tierney

Eastern Shore resident advocates for sustainable seafood on Capitol Hill

 WASHINGTON, D.C. — Oyster farmer Imani Black has stepped off the boat and onto Capitol Hill with 21 members of the Coalition for Sustainable Aquaculture to urge lawmakers to support sustainable seafood in American open ocean waters.The coalition is familiar with the suits, high heels and high rotunda ceiling on the Hill after consistently supporting science-based, inclusive off-shore aquaculture bills, according to the Coalition for Sustainable Aquaculture's Website.
Black founded nonprofit Minorities in Aquaculture in 2020. The organization educates underserved communities about the growing opportunities in aquaculture, its benefits and sustainability and sustainability's lasting impact.
Black, an Easton resident, is an Eastern Shore native through and through and works in oyster restoration. "I just think there's so much power in a little oyster," Black said. "And they do so much for us. In the water and out of the water."
Oysters clean the Chesapeake Bay through filter feeding, which helps clarify the water; nutrient cycling, which allows oysters to process nitrogen in a way that removes it from the water; and through habitat creation, where oyster reefs can provide essential habitat for other marine species.
Her waterman heritage and Chesapeake culture heavily inspired Black's involvement in this type of work. She said she is proud of her Eastern Shore heritage and seeks to honor her family's legacy by representing the region.
"I love being on the Eastern Shore so much," Black said. "I mean, I may not like living here sometimes because we don't have a lot of stuff, but I love the essence and I love the culture."
Minorities in Aquaculture's mission focuses on workforce development. Black said that sometimes, the name can be a deterrent, but once people get past the buzz words of diversity, equity and inclusion, they start to understand the importance of this work.
"If we are going to have U.S. seafood competitiveness increasing like this administration wants us to, we're going to need skilled labor to be able to do that," she said. "And so it doesn't really matter if you're Black, white, purple or, whatever, we need you and your skills."
Black and the 21 members of the coalition went to D.C. to advocate for consensus legislation that aims to create federal regulations and guidelines surrounding aquaculture, such as permitting and site regulations, fish health and welfare measures, labor and equity standards, and climate and sustainability standards.
Black said the bill has seen a tremendous amount of support, especially in Maryland and Virginia, but there is excitement and growing interest elsewhere too.
{p class="p1"}"I think that people are getting more curious and want to strengthen their connection and understanding to agriculture and what's going on and things like that," Black said.
Black said if anyone is interested in following along with this new initiative or her other work or wants to get involved, they should visit the website mianpo.org.

title: 'Barge-r' than life: Wye River Oyster Program ensures 21 million oysters in Wye River

'Barge-r' than life: Wye River Oyster Program ensures 21 million oysters in Wye River

 WYE RIVER — A small but mighty group of citizens, friends and neighbors dedicated to the preservation of the Chesapeake Bay, Wye River Oyster Program volunteers raised donations to plant 21 million spat-on-shell oysters to cover three acres of the Wye River bottom June 29.Focusing hyper local efforts, the Wye River Oyster Program is a non-profit, community initiative to restore oyster populations in the local Wye River.
The Chesapeake Bay is "the only water system like it in the world," and residents who live on the water are a unique community, regularly sharing information about the water and its resources, organizer Steve Burleson said.
Dedicated to the preservation of the watershed, the ball began rolling about a year ago, according to Burleson, when citizens gathered to see what additional initiatives could be done to further restoration efforts.
While conservancy groups are invaluable in education and advocacy, Wye River Oyster Program volunteers sought to have more direct and local impacts and discovered the Wye River as an oyster sanctuary right in their own backyard.
With little more than an idea and a talking point, the Wye River Oyster program hatched, with all-volunteer efforts ensuring 100% of donations go toward purchase of spat on shells, he said.
"This way we know exactly where the money is going," he said.
Every little bit helps, especially with the growing uncertainty of federal funding, he noted.
Primarily through word of mouth with other water enthusiasts, Wye River Oyster Program quickly raised money to partner with Ricky Fitzhugh of Seed to Shuck Ventures, and cover three acres of the Wye River bottom.
Based in Cambridge, Seed to Shuck's hatchery spawns new oyster larvae for spat on shell production and restoration projects on the Bay.
Seed to Shuck is an active partner with federal and state agencies, conservation organizations and watermen to plant new growth in oyster sanctuaries, public fisheries and private leases in Maryland and Virginia.
Each canister is home to approximately 675 bushels of oysters and the initiative planted three canisters, which makes up one barge, Burleson said.
According to Maryland Department of Natural Resources (DNR) estimates, about 15% of spat on shell grow to market size, and the DNR has been incredibly supportive of the initiative, he said.
An essential aspect of an entire ecology, oysters naturally filter pollutants and excess nutrients in the water and their reefs help restore submerged habitat, providing shelter and breeding grounds for a variety of marine life, according to Burleson.
By restoring oyster beds to historic areas, the Wye River Oyster Program aims to achieve significant improvements to the water quality of the Wye River for the benefit of the community and the ecosystem of the Chesapeake watershed.
Community interest throughout the entire initiative has been highly engaging, and supportive, Burleson said.
Several boats with numerous volunteers and river enthusiasts took to the water to watch the planting Sunday, June 29. The shell is washed off the boat onto the waiting river floor below the surface.
The Wye River Oyster Program seeks to make plantings an annual tradition and encourage more neighboring rivers to join in initiatives to locally support their waterways, according to Burleson.
The Wye River Oyster Program Fund is a non-profit of the Mid Shore Community Foundation.
More information about Seed to Shuck Ventures can be found at seedtoshuck.com.

 The St. Mary's River in Southern Maryland received about 25,500 new — and very welcome — residents last week when members of the Supporting Oyster Aquaculture and Restoration program planted oysters on an established sanctuary about a mile from the St. Mary's College of Maryland docks.SOAR, as the program is known, buys oysters from local growers that could not otherwise be used for sale to help build and support reefs in the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries.
"Oysters are incredibly valuable to the Chesapeake Bay ecosystem as the three F's," St. Mary's River Watershed Association Executive Director Emma Ewing said, referring to filtering, fish and food. "They filter water, provide habitat for striped bass, white perch and blue crabs, and people love to eat oysters and a lot of people rely on oysters for their job and their livelihoods."
Ewing added that each adult oyster can filter up to 50 gallons of water a day.
Tall Timbers-based Shore Thing Shellfish was contracted to load, move and deploy the oysters, as well as for assistance with site selection and ongoing monitoring.
The program was started by The Nature Conservancy and the Pew Charitable Trust during the coronavirus pandemic to help growers who were impacted by restaurant closures.
"Oysters are an iconic species for the Chesapeake," The Nature Conservancy Chesapeake Bay Director Amy Jacobs said. "They are [overlooked] and even though we've made great progress through restoration we're still at a very, very small percent of what we used to have historically, so the more we can support oyster restoration and get more oysters in the water and allow for the growth of both aquaculture and wild harvest and restoration through sanctuaries, and have all those work together, the better the bay is going to be."
The conservancy provided funding for the oyster purchases through the SOAR program and worked with the Maryland Department of Natural Resources along with local partners and stakeholders.
"You want to make sure different year classes [of oysters] are in the water at all time," The Nature Conservancy SOAR Lead Dan Sweeney said, "because if one year-class gets infected by some mortality event, having [them from multiple classes] will help replenish and grow more baby oysters."
A news release said the June 30 replanting was a "great opportunity to highlight the importance of oysters to Maryland both economically and ecologically, and the role that local growers can play in their restoration."
Oyster growers Jon Farrington of Johnny Oyster Seed Company in St. Leonard, Phillip Stephens of Loose Stones Oyster Company in Hollywood and Joseph C. Gardener supplied 85 bushels of oysters, which equates to about 25,500 oysters.
"I'm always a big proponent of the environmental work that oysters do and so when we can farm oysters and make money on them, whether they're being sold for food or restoration purposes, it's all good," said Farrington, who called oysters "habitat engineers."
According to Ewing, the St. Mary's River Watershed Association began planting oysters in the river in 2013 and it became an oyster sanctuary in 2017.
"I'd say [the oysters make] a big difference," Ewing said. "Talking to the guys on the waterfront who are out here every day they say the water's clearer and we've definitely seen more fish, blue crabs. This area right here the 5-acre reef site is an extremely popular fishing and crabbing area because of all the oysters we've put in this area."

title: Oyster regulations to remain unchanged in upcoming season
author: BROOKE ENSMINGER

Oyster regulations to remain unchanged in upcoming season

 July 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BROOKE ENSMINGER | Section: Dorchester Star

 Maryland will maintain its current oyster harvest regulations for the 2025-26 season, even as oyster populations increase in many areas, the Maryland Department of Natural Resources announced in a press release last month.These regulations include rules on daily catch limits, the number of weekly harvest days and temporary area closures.
"Keeping the harvest limits as they are will contribute to stability and sustainability over time," DNR media relations manager Gregg Bortz said. Bortz said the decision to maintain, rather than increase, harvest limits was made to manage the fishery and oyster population conservatively.
In making its decision, DNR considered the new benchmark oyster stock assessment, harvest data trends and the fall survey results from 2023 and 2024.
Results from the stock assessment show oyster populations have increased in most areas over the past five years.
Unlike in other areas, the assessment shows oyster abundance in the Chester River continues to decline. As a result, the river will be closed to harvest in the upcoming season, except for fishery plantings.
The 2014 Chesapeake Bay Watershed Agreement set 2025 as the goal for fully restoring oyster habitats in five Chesapeake Bay tributaries. Maryland is on track to reach that goal by the end of the year, according to Allison Colden, Maryland executive director of the Chesapeake Bay Foundation.
"Now that we know what works and how to do restoration efficiently, we should be able to achieve at least the same level of restoration, if not more, than we have over the past 10 years," Colden said.
According to Colden, the results from this year's assessment are promising, but oysters are still at risk from disease and events that could cause mass die-offs. Population levels necessary for long-term sustainability have not been reached in some areas throughout the Bay.
"That's why continued investment and rebuilding efforts are so important to keep the population sustainable," Colden said.
Harvest rules are established annually by DNR based on the status of the oyster population. While future regulations cannot be predicted, Colden said she hopes responsible harvesting of oysters remains a priority.
"We believe that, even though we're seeing a significant growth in the oyster population, it'll remain critical for DNR to stay the course and maintain its harvest regulations for the foreseeable future," Colden said.
The commercial oyster season runs from Oct. 1, 2025, through March 31, 2026 for use of patent tongs, hand tongs and divers. For power dredge and sail dredge, the season runs from Nov. 1, 2025, through March 31, 2026.
Commercial harvesters are permitted to catch oysters Monday through Friday. Daily catch limits vary depending on the equipment used.
The recreational season runs from Oct. 1, 2025, through March 31, 2026. Recreational harvesters are limited to one bushel per person per day and may harvest oysters Monday through Saturday.

title: USDA secretary, Andy Harris announce $6M in grants for blue catfish processors

USDA secretary, Andy Harris announce $6M in grants for blue catfish processors

 TILGHMAN ISLAND — Nick Hargrove's business has operated as the Eastern Shore's only blue catfish processing facility for more than two years, cutting almost five million pounds of the invasive species since opening."Five million pounds might sound like a lot," said Hargrove, owner of Tilghman Island Seafood. "But with an estimated almost 1 billion pounds swimming around in this Chesapeake Bay, it's gonna take a much larger effort to be able to stop this fish from eating all the things that we love in this state."
A step in that broader effort was announced last Wednesday at Hargrove's facility, which sits just past Tilghman Island's drawbridge. Hargrove was flanked behind a podium by U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Brooke Rollins, Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md., 1st) and state agriculture officials.
Rollins and Harris announced two efforts to aid the processing industry for wild-caught blue catfish, a species that outcompetes its Chesapeake Bay counterparts and preys on native fish and blue crabs.
First, the USDA is opening $6 million in grant funding to seafood processors, a move Rollins and Harris say will help get the processing industry off its feet.
Harris said it's all about beefing up the commercial market for current and new wild-caught blue catfish processors. He hopes more facilities like Tilghman Island Seafood pop up on the Eastern Shore.
"The bottom line is we have to do something. I hope it's not too late," Harris said. "I think it's not if we can get this going. But the way to do it is to make sure we can develop a commercial market."
Individual grants will range from $250,000 to $1 million, per the USDA. Applicants must cover 50% of their total project cost. The application deadline is Oct. 6.
Hargrove said without grant dollars, his business is often "paralyzed" with how many blue catfish it can process and sell. He's sent shipments as far as San Francisco and Hong Kong.
The newly revealed available grant money could make a significant difference, Hargrove said.
"Hopefully, with this money, we can really automate a lot of our processes," he said.
For the second effort, Rollins announced the USDA, jointly with the Maryland Department of Agriculture, will purchase up to $2 million of Chesapeake Bay blue catfish in a one-year pilot.
The purchases will be done through USDA's Section 32 program, Rollins noted, directing food toward low-income areas and residents.
"This dual effort will support regional processors, remove invasive catfish from the Chesapeake Bay and produce nutritious protein to American families," Rollins said.
Hargrove took Rollins, Harris and other officials through Tilghman Island Seafood's facility before the formal press conference on Wednesday. Employees showed the process of readying the catfish, and one worker even gave the agriculture secretary a hands-on demonstration on how to properly slice a catfish.
Rollins said she was impressed by the Tilghman Island Seafood employees and the product they put out.
"To see it firsthand, to meet the workers, to see what happens out on the water, and to see the business that is being built and how we in the government can really help to support that is a big takeaway as I go back to D.C.," Rollins said.

"I asked a question in there: had they thought about 3D printing oyster shells? Now, why would I ask that question? I was in Japan for the World Fair just a few months ago, and they were 3D printing coral and reintroducing that back into the ocean and would reintegrate and grow new coral. So it's those kinds of questions that I think about. How can we best fortify the industry?" Chaves-DeRemer said following the tour.
She said her goal is to complete the remaining 14 states by the first week of December in hopes to provide timely, actionable feedback to President Donald Trump within the first year of both of their terms.
Chavez-DeRemer said feedback from the tour will shape workforce programs and federal grant decisions. She said the Labor Department's focus on jobs and training reflects the administration's priorities of accountability, innovation and community strength.
Chaves-DeRemer emphasized the "Make America Skilled Again" grants, which are intended to flow to state and local partners and fund targeted workforce needs, including apprenticeships. The hatchery had one apprentice last cycle and aims for two more next year.
Alexander said she personally funded the apprenticeship in the previous year and that it was nice to hear of other potential funding opportunities.
"My ideal apprentice would be somebody who has ties to the oyster industry, who is looking to do things different than what has historically been done. I think that would be amazing to foster connections, not only between the industry and our community, but the environment," Alexander said.
When asked about how to stimulate the workforce amid federal budget cuts, Chaves-DeRemer said the department is focused on preventing waste, fraud and abuse, aligning with Trump's budget with economic goals, which were central to his campaign and the early months of his current term.
She said this is done through inter-agency collaboration via memorandum of understandings.
The federal administration says it is cutting waste by modernizing operations such as using technology like AI, streamlining compliance programs, and upgrading systems to prevent fraud and inefficiency.
"Two out of every three new jobs is created by a small business owner," Chaves-DeRemer said. "So right here in Maryland, this industry is important. It's important to the ancillary jobs that it will affect. So the more we grow this economy, the better off and more prosperity we'll have."
Alexander hopes there will be future collaboration with the Department of Labor to build a highly skilled workforce in Maryland, especially in Cambridge.
Chaves-DeRemer said she is committed to personally conveying state-level insights to the president and coordinating across agency leadership for implementation.
"You really cannot understand what's happening on the ground and how it affects the local economy, the everyday average worker in America, unless you can talk to them," she said. "So I wouldn't know about this laboratory unless I'm here on site to hear these reports, to understand the lovely woman who gave me the tour. She started off as an intern and 29 years later, here she is, talking about why the oyster industry is so important."
